Recall that strategy involves making commitment-rich choices in the face of uncertainty. Once you have developed scenarios, it’s helpful to categorize the various moves your business could make. McKinsey’s Strategy Method offers three broad categories defined in terms of:

    • the level of commitment
    • the risk of being wrong

Click each category to learn more. When you are finished, scroll down to hear Bloomberg leaders talk about how they balance making a high-commitment choice with flexibility.


No-Regret Moves

A No-Regret move will pay off in almost any circumstance. A highly repeatable move—such as opening the thousandth store in a territory where all previous 999 have been successful—will typically be a No-Regret move. Other examples might include investment in initiatives to improve customer service or customer retention.


Big Bets

Big Bets are large commitments with a high risk of being wrong. Typical examples include major capital investments or acquisitions that will produce large payoffs in some scenarios and large losses in others. Therefore, there is a high risk of being wrong—exposure to downside is significant. While the Big Bet may be the right move, a common mistake businesses make is to commit to unnecessary Big Bets when less risky Real Options, such as running a pilot, create more flexibility and offer reduced exposure to downside.

Real Options

Real Options are small, high-risk investments that businesses can scale up as they learn more about the commercial environment in which the strategy is playing out. Essentially, a Real Option offers limited exposure to downside, but the upside can be significant. This is sometimes termed an “asymmetric bet.” Typical examples include conducting a pilot before the full-scale introduction of a new product or entering into a limited joint venture to minimize the risks inherent in breaking into a new market. Licensing a limited-scale deployment of a third-party technology in case it proves to be superior to the technology your business could develop in-house would also be considered a Real Option. In these examples, you would have learned enough from the Real Options to be confident in making a high-commitment move that’s relatively certain of success (and therefore not a Big Bet). Another way of putting this is with reference to this diagram: The aim of your strategy should be to move “north-west” and not “north.” You should be progressing from a low-risk, low-commitment Real Options (bottom right of the diagram) towards a high-commitment, low-risk No-Regret move (top left).

However, sometimes you would miss the window of opportunity if you go for a Real Option rather than directly for a Big Bet. This happens in cases where there is a first mover advantage or a “winner takes all” dynamic. Rigorous analysis as part of the Strategy Method can help you determine whether it’s wise to convert your Big Bet to a Real Option (or series of Real Options)—or whether, by doing this, you’d miss out on the opportunity.
